recommendations.name: Seito Masamune Tantanmen Tsujita
recommendations.area: Multiple locations (Ogawamachi, Kojimachi, Ichigaya, and more)
recommendations.description: Key's personal favorite. Authentic Chengdu-style tantanmen by Tsujita (of tsukemen fame) — 18 locations across Japan. Rich sesame broth with customizable spice levels (Key goes level 3). Counter seating at most spots.

recommendations.name: SHIBIRE NOODLES Rousokuya (蝋燭屋)
recommendations.area: Multiple locations (Ginza honten, Omotesando Hills, Kyobashi Edogran)
recommendations.description: Famous mapo tofu noodles (mabo men) — Sichuan peppercorn-heavy, tongue-numbing, deeply addictive. Also serves tantanmen and hot & sour noodles. Expect a line at lunch, especially the Ginza flagship.

recommendations.name: Nogami (乃が美)
recommendations.description: Luxury shokupan (Japanese milk bread) — impossibly soft, slightly sweet, no toaster needed. One of Japan's most famous bakeries. Gift-worthy loaves. Cash only.

recommendations.name: Pizza Studio Tamaki (PST)
recommendations.description: One of Tokyo's most highly regarded pizzerias. Neapolitan-style with impeccable technique. Locations in Roppongi and Higashi-Azabu.

recommendations.name: Savoy
recommendations.description: Legendary Neapolitan pizza — margherita and marinara done to perfection. The main location rarely has a huge wait if you show up ~30min early. Their second spot down the street (Savoy Tomato & Cheese) almost never has a wait at opening.

recommendations.name: KNOCK Cucina Buona Italiana
recommendations.description: Casual Italian done right — good pasta, pizza, and wine in a relaxed setting. Locations in both Roppongi Hills and Tokyo Midtown. Easy, reliable pick.

recommendations.name: CRISP SALAD WORKS
recommendations.area: Multiple locations (Roppongi Midtown, Daikanyama, Mita, and more)
recommendations.description: NYC-style chopped salads in Tokyo — ~30 toppings to customize your bowl. Fresh, high-quality ingredients. Great healthy option when you need a break from all the ramen and katsu.

recommendations.name: Blacows
recommendations.description: Premium wagyu burgers — one of the most popular burger joints in Tokyo. Rich, juicy patties with quality toppings. Always busy for a reason.

recommendations.name: Aldebaran
recommendations.description: Widely considered the best burger in Japan. Thick wagyu patty cooked to perfect medium rare. Hamburger shop by day, bar by night. Small and intimate — feels like family.

recommendations.name: Maisen (まい泉)
recommendations.description: Iconic tonkatsu since 1965 — housed in a converted bathhouse near Omotesando Station. Huge space so easy to eat without a long wait. Multiple locations across Tokyo.

recommendations.name: Nemuro Hanamaru (根室花まる)
recommendations.description: One of Tokyo's best conveyor belt sushi spots — Hokkaido-fresh fish at incredible prices. On the 10th floor. Pro tip: get in line at the elevator an hour before opening or you'll be waiting forever.

recommendations.name: Imakatsu (イマカツ)
recommendations.description: The best chicken katsu in Tokyo. Their sasami katsu (chicken fillet) from Iwate Prefecture contract farm will change how you think about chicken breast — impossibly juicy and tender. Multiple locations including Roppongi and Ginza.

recommendations.name: Butagumi (豚組)
recommendations.description: The original — hallowed tonkatsu in a quaint residential house. Choose your cut and prefecture's brand-name pork. Michelin Bib Gourmand.

recommendations.name: Butagumi Dining (豚組食堂)
recommendations.description: Casual sibling of Butagumi — same incredible pork, more accessible setting. Great lunch deal until 3:15pm. Popular with international diners.

recommendations.name: Sobamae Yamato (蕎麦前 山都)
recommendations.description: Elegant soba spot on the first floor of Roppongi Hills. Handmade buckwheat noodles in a refined open-kitchen setting. Great for a proper soba-mae experience (appetizers + soba).

recommendations.name: Shin Udon (慎)
recommendations.description: World-famous udon brasserie — the viral carbonara udon is a must, but everything here is incredible. Handmade noodles with perfect chew. Featured in Bon Appétit. Expect a line.

recommendations.name: Fuunji (風雲児)
recommendations.description: One of Tokyo's best tsukemen — rich, intense chicken and fish dipping broth with thick noodles. Always a line but it moves fast. Counter seating, vending machine ordering.

recommendations.name: Mugi to Olive (むぎとオリーブ)
recommendations.description: Michelin Bib Gourmand ramen — famous for their Triple Soba made with chicken, dried sardines, and hamaguri clam broth. Refined, light, and deeply flavorful. Behind Ginza Six. Expect a queue at lunch.

recommendations.name: Yakumo (八雲)
recommendations.description: One of Tokyo's best wonton ramen spots. Famous for white (shio) and black (shoyu) dashi wontonmen — delicate, refined broth with plump handmade wontons. Cash only, vending machine ordering. Expect a wait.
